image.altText: Anthony Albanese frowns during a press conference.

items.synopsis: A No vote is recorded nationally and in all six states as the Voice to Parliament proposal is defeated in Australia's first referendum this century. Follow all the results with our live blog.

title.children: PM says nation must seek 'new way forward' after voters in all six states vote No to Voice

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: These are the 10 seats with the strongest No vote. They are largely in regional areas. They include Maranoa in far south-western Queensland, the seat of Nationals leader David Littleproud, as well as Bob Katter's seat of Kennedy, directly to the north of Maranoa.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The seats with the strongest No result

children.content: These are
the 10 seats with the strongest No vote
. They are largely in regional areas.
They include
Maranoa
in far south-western Queensland, the seat of
Nationals leader David Littleproud
, as well as
Bob Katter's
seat of
Kennedy
, directly to the north of Maranoa.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Votes are still being counted, but it looks like a few dozen electorates across the country have voted Yes. These are the 10 seats with the strongest Yes vote so far. Inner-city seats in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra dominate. They include Melbourne, held by the Greens leader Adam Bandt, with a Yes vote of nearly 80 per cent. In Grayndler, held by the prime minister, more than three-quarters of people voted Yes on the latest count. There are also seats held by teal independents on the list.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The electorates with the highest Yes vote

children.content: Votes are still being counted, but it looks like a few dozen electorates across the country have voted Yes.
These are the 10 seats with the strongest Yes vote so far.
Inner-city seats in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra dominate.
They include
Melbourne
, held by the Greens leader Adam Bandt, with a Yes vote of nearly 80 per cent.
In
Grayndler
, held by the prime minister, more than three-quarters of people voted Yes on the latest count.
There are also seats held by teal independents on the list.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Voice has been rejected by voters in all Australian states. After less than an hour of counting, the ABC now projects the Voice has been defeated in Western Australia. The referendum has also failed to gain a majority of voters nationally. The ACT was the only jurisdiction to vote Yes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ABC projection: All states have voted against the Voice

children.content: The Voice has been
rejected by voters in all Australian states
After less than an hour of counting, the ABC now projects the Voice has been
defeated in Western Australia
The referendum has also failed to gain a majority of voters nationally.
The ACT was the only jurisdiction to vote Yes.

image.altText: A woman holding her baby standing in front of a school building

items.synopsis: Western Australians were still lining up to cast their votes for more than an hour and a half after the national result was known – here’s how that played out.

title.children: Western Australians learn of Voice referendum defeat while waiting in line to vote

image.altText: A hand holds an Aboriginal flag in front of a large banner

items.synopsis: Australians have rejected recognising Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as the nation's first people in the constitution through the establishment of a Voice to Parliament advisory body.

title.children: Australians reject Indigenous recognition via Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A pile of referendum ballot papers being counted

items.synopsis: Antony Green projects a majority No vote nationally and in four states. Our full results guide breaks down the numbers.

title.children: Voice referendum results: Follow the count across the country

image.altText: The back of a woman with a vest saying Australian Official on it

items.synopsis: A flight for Australians to evacuate Israel has been cancelled, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has announced. Follow live.

title.children: Repatriation flights cancelled for Australians as Israel issues six-hour window for evacuations from Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A rocket has been fired close to Israel’s main airport, Ben Gurion, from the Gaza Strip. It landed in the town of Kfar Habad, about 2 kilometres from the airport. It was not known what damage it caused. The rocket and the fact that Hamas appears to be targeting the airport could explain the Australian Government’s decision to cancel further repatriation flights. Yesterday, a Qantas flight with 238 people left Ben Gurion for Heathrow. It was free for Australian citizens who wanted to leave due to the war between Israel and Gaza. But unexpectedly today the government announced that other repatriation flights would be cancelled. The reason for the sudden cancellation could be that Australian intelligence has received information that Hamas will escalate its attacks on the airport in the event of an Israeli ground invasion. Scores of flights have been cancelled as airlines decide not to take the risk of an attack.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rocket lands near airport after Qantas cancels flights

children.content: A rocket has been fired close to Israel’s main airport, Ben Gurion, from the Gaza Strip.
It landed in the town of Kfar Habad, about 2 kilometres from the airport. It was not known what damage it caused.
The rocket and the fact that Hamas appears to be targeting the airport could explain the Australian Government’s decision to cancel further repatriation flights.

Yesterday, a Qantas flight with 238 people left Ben Gurion for Heathrow. It was free for Australian citizens who wanted to leave due to the war between Israel and Gaza. But unexpectedly today the government announced that other repatriation flights would be cancelled.
The reason for the sudden cancellation could be that Australian intelligence has received information that Hamas will escalate its attacks on the airport in the event of an Israeli ground invasion.
Scores of flights have been cancelled as airlines decide not to take the risk of an attack.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israel Defense Force (IDF) says it has targeted a company of Hamas 'Nukhba' commando forces who led the Hamas terror attack against Israeli villages near the border with Gaza last week. "Based on precise IDF and ISA intelligence, IDF aircraft killed Ali Qadi, a company commander of the Hamas 'Nukhba' commando force, who led the terror attack in Israeli communities near the Gaza Strip last weekend," it said in a statement on Telegram. According to Israel's Meir Amit Intelligence and Terrorism Information Center, Ali was one of two Hamas militants who kidnapped an Israeli named Sasson Nuriel in 2005, at the factory where he worked in Ramallah. The pair were arrested and then later released as part of a prisoner exchange for the return of a kidnapped Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit, in 2011. Earlier today, the IDF said it had also killed a militant named Merad Abu Merad, who was the head of the Hamas aerial system.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says it has killed a Hamas commander who led the attack

children.content: The Israel Defense Force (IDF) says it has targeted a company of Hamas 'Nukhba' commando forces who led the Hamas terror attack against Israeli villages near the border with Gaza last week.

"Based on precise IDF and ISA intelligence, IDF aircraft killed Ali Qadi, a company commander of the Hamas 'Nukhba' commando force, who led the terror attack in Israeli communities near the Gaza Strip last weekend," it said in a statement on Telegram.
According to
Israel's Meir Amit Intelligence and Terrorism Information Center
, Ali was one of two Hamas militants who kidnapped an Israeli named Sasson Nuriel in 2005, at the factory where he worked in Ramallah.
The pair were arrested and then later released as part of a prisoner exchange for the return of a kidnapped Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit, in 2011.
Earlier today, the IDF said it had also killed a militant named Merad Abu Merad, who was the head of the Hamas aerial system.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Palestinian Health Ministry has reported 324 Palestinians have been killed and 1,000 injured in the past 24 hours. The death toll in the conflict has surpassed 3,500 on both sides and continues to soar. Since the conflict began last weekend at least 2,215 Palestinians have been killed and 8,714 wounded in Israeli air attacks on Gaza. Another 54 Palestinians were killed and 1,100 wounded in the West Bank according to the Health Ministry. In Israel the death toll has reached 1,300, with 3,400 wounded according to the Israeli Defense Force.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian Health Ministry reports 324 deaths in Gaza since yesterday

children.content: The Palestinian Health Ministry has reported 324 Palestinians have been killed and 1,000 injured in the past 24 hours.
The death toll in the conflict has surpassed 3,500 on both sides and continues to soar.
Since the conflict began last weekend at least 2,215 Palestinians have been killed and 8,714 wounded in Israeli air attacks on Gaza.
Another 54 Palestinians were killed and 1,100 wounded in the West Bank according to the Health Ministry.
In Israel the death toll has reached 1,300, with 3,400 wounded according to the Israeli Defense Force.

image.altText: A map of Australia against a background of orange and purple stripes.

image.altText: A person in a crowd holds up a sign with the Aboriginal flag and the words "Voice to Parliament".

image.altText: Jack Darling kicks a goal

image.altText: Virgin, Qantas planes

items.synopsis: Some of the recommendations of a new report would shift power away from Qantas — such as by giving travellers automatic cash compensation for delayed or cancelled flights, write Gui Lohmann and Justin Wastnage.

title.children: Qantas won't like it, but Australian travellers could be about to get a better deal on flights

image.altText: A woman holding a large handbag and wearing a scarf who looks wealthy walks the street.

title.children: In their distorted Cinderella legend, the Beckhams get the last laugh

image.altText: An Aboriginal elder looks out of frame, with beautiful native trees in the background.

title.children: In 1967, a man holding ballot papers approached Brian Champion in the bush. Now he's preparing to vote 'yes' again

image.altText: A woman sobs as people stand against a sandstone wall at a funeral

items.synopsis: Israel is preparing to carry out a ground operation with a mission to "destroy Hamas". But what then? What is the political reality and make-up of Gaza and what would it look like without Hamas, asks John Lyons.

title.children: A reeling Israel is on the brink of razing Gaza – and the outlook is grim

image.altText: Long purple petals opening up from the yellow centre of a flower.

items.synopsis: Indigenous horticulturalists have taken 21 cuttings of the first known purple Banksia spinulosa. But it remains to be seen whether they will flower, and what colour the petals will be.

image.altText: Costa, who has long hair and a bushy beard, smiles against a blue backdrop, with images of a cheese toastie and kimchi.

items.synopsis: If we're being honest, Costa's known for one thing: the delightfully enormous beard covering half his face. We sat down with the Gardening Australia host to find out if his big beard really is full of secrets.

title.children: Eating burgers with a knife and fork and even killing houseplants: Costa reveals his darkest secrets

image.altText: A woman walks past "vote yes" and "vote no" signs on a fence.

items.synopsis: The nation is bound for the ballot box today to cast their vote in a referendum that could shape the country for generations to come — but the path to this poll has been a rocky one.

image.altText: a ballot paper is dropping in a sealed ballot box with a purple lid

items.synopsis: It's been revealed authorities were warned about the worsening state of a 16-year now old fighting for his life in hospital two weeks before his suicide attempt in the youth wing of an adult prison.

image.altText: composite of fire truck for western australia fire service, people at a beach side pool in sydney and people skiing in perisher

title.children: Heat in the west and snow in the south-east — here's what is driving Australia's stark weather contrasts

title.children: Naturists 'completely locked out' of South Australian nude beach

title.children: Australia coasts to easy win in final ODI against West Indies

image.altText: A Cruise driverless taxi in San Francisco

items.synopsis: A recent Californian trial saw self-driving taxis crash into a fire truck and get bogged in wet cement. Such incidents erode trust in the technology, writes autonomous systems researcher Zena Assaad.

title.children: San Francisco's driverless taxis marked a new era in transportation. Then the problems started

image.altText: A range of old cars in a car museum.

items.synopsis: Experts believe the future of vehicles will include a mix of technologies as the planet becomes more environmentally conscious.

title.children: As the world becomes more environmentally conscious, what does this mean for classic and prestige car lovers?

image.altText: A young woman gazes at a magenta flower

items.synopsis: When Lauren Bouyer tries to conjure an image in her mind's eye, nothing happens. Researchers say her condition, aphantasia, is more prevalent than previously thought.

title.children: Loren can't 'see' things in her imagination. It's more common than you might think
